title: Moravian Academy-Southern Lehigh field hockey rivalry is intense but classy
text:
Katie Persin sensed things were getting a little chippy on Wednesday night. 
So the Moravian Academy field hockey senior let her actions take over on the field. 
Persin scored the final goal with 9:35 remaining to seal the Lions’ 3-0 win over Southern Lehigh in the Colonial League championship game at Salisbury High School. 
It was the second straight league title for Moravian (19-1), which defeated Southern Lehigh (18-2) for the second time this season. 
“I was running down the field pretty far and these (Southern Lehigh) girls were jabbing at me,” Persin said. “I was getting frustrated, so I pounded it in.” 
Persin made it clear, however, that those things happen in the heat of the battle, and every game against Southern Lehigh is always good clean competition. 
RELATED : Moravian Academy field hockey is a time bomb waiting to explode 
“They’re our biggest rival, and they’re definitely physical,” Persin said, “but every time we play them they’re always classy just like us.” 
Southern Lehigh kept the Lions off the scoreboard until sophomore Ashley Pearce notched a goal with 20:55 left in the game. Junior Mayv Clune also scored and assisted on Pearce’s goal. 
Despite the three-goal loss, Spartans coach Adrienne Searfoss couldn’t have asked for more from her team. 
“They did everything I asked of them,” an emotional Searfoss said. “I couldn’t be prouder. That’s the best we’ve played all year. They gave 100 percent.” 
Moravian coach Debbie Bross again gave props to her stout midfield trio of Persin, Cecily Redfern and Vivian Simone . 
“The midfielders played great, and we have a solid defense behind us,” Bross said. 
Bross sensed her team was in the driver’s seat when Pearce broke the scoreless tie. 
“Our A.D. (athletic director Manny Oudin) came up to me and said ‘Once we put one in, we got this,”’ Bross said. “It was just a matter of time. We felt pretty secure.” 
Even when Moravian scored, Searfoss felt her defenders were in excellent position. 
“We were right on people,” Searfoss said. “Those goals they scored, they were legit goals.” 
According to Persin, it was Moravian’s only loss of the season, last Friday’s 3-2 setback at Whitehall, that helped prepare the team for this tournament. 
“That (loss) hurt a lot because wanted to go undefeated,” Persin said, “but we needed to play that game because it was on turf and it helped prepare us for this turf field (at Salisbury). I think that was the first time we played on turf all year. But that loss helped us win this game.”
